--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> So do you foresee your system being used by people 
> with little expertise who want
> to be able to quickly set up experiments, or more
> by serious researchers setting up very efficient 
> distributed experiments?  

Well, we hope it will be user-friendly. :)

We're going to include XOR, Tic-Tac-Toe, and probably
a distributed Tic-Tac-Toe that can run on multiple
machines in a networked environment.

We'll try to make it as easy as possible to set up and
start playing with it.  Whoever uses it is going to
have to write their own fitness function in Java (or
modify one of the existing examples).  But hopefully
the code will be reasonably clear and well-documented.
:)

We're using JavaParty

http://www.ipd.uka.de/JavaParty/

for the distributed environment, and hopefully between
our Tic-Tac-Toe example, their benchmark examples, and
our documentation, it shouldn't be *too* difficult to
program a fitness function for a distributed
environment (we're not distributing everything, just
the fitness evaluations).  

Since it's Java-based, there shouldn't be any problems
running it in a heterogenous distributed environment
(we're currently developing and testing it in a 5-node
environment with both WinXP on the master node and
Redhat 9.0 on the slaves).

> In other words, are you
> trying to have an easy-to-use interface?

Our first version will probably just have to be run
from a command line, but all the evolutionary
parameters can be defined in a single text file.  But
one of the earliest features we want to implement is
an HTML interface in which you can enter values for
parameters (such as mutation rates, compatibility
threshold values, etc.), and just click a "run"
button.  We liked the way Ugo's version displays the
topology of individuals, so we'll be doing something
similar (a dedicated browser window which displays the
fittest individual, in SVG format).

If you're not familiar with SVG, check here:

http://www.adobe.com/svg/main.html

We've got two SVG layout algorithms for the ANN
topologies, one that displays the neural net in
layers, the other in a spiral pattern.  I've uploaded
samples of one small and one larger network displayed
both ways into the Photos section of our Yahoo Group
page:

http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/lst

These are GIFs.  The actual SVGs are better quality
and since they're rendered in vector graphics, they
scale without loss of visual quality.

We hope that the technology and the approach we're
using will make for a relatively easy-to-use,
easy-to-modify, Java-based implementation.  We're
planning on opensourcing it on SourceForge, hopefully
by the end of year, but we don't really know when. 
I'll definitely announce here when that happens.  I
hope some people will find it useful, and accumulate
more domains/fitness functions for it, but we'll see.

Derek
